Z Slider for Foldarap 2.5.
I found with the standard z slider the nuts would move and cause the z slider to misalign itself.
When installing heat the nuts with either a heat gun or flame. This will cause the nut to seat itself nicely into the sliders nut pocket. alternatively adjust the width of the nut pocket. mine is currently 7.4mm however the correct width off an M5 nut from flat to flat on the nut is about 8mm.

author: bardiir

description.text: Boat

I tried the VORON case first and wasn`t that satisifed, so i tried the one from dazza26, which is roughly what i wanted :)

I reworked the case from dazza26. Actually, i designed it 95% new :)

The drill pattern for 50mm fans seems to be slightly different depending on the manufacturer, so i didn`t put any holes - drill as needed.

You can mount it on a 30x30 extrusion profile as you like. You will need two 50mm fans, they will be placed right above the stepper drivers.

Mount the case to the profile, then push the LCD cables through - now mount the board.

I used the MKS Gen 1.4 Board from RepRap Discount and Revoltec 50mm fans. Please compare the board design before you print this. I will add some changes and pictures as i currently build my new printer.

title: Assassin's Creed Modern Hidden Blade (Connor Style) - Open Source

description.text:
Update 1.0 - Special thanks to Flo Zum / djflo68260 for helping in finding mistakes... Merci beaucoup.

ENGLISH:

A modernized design of the Hidden Blade of Assassin's Creed III mainly conceived for Cosplay. Free/Open Source so anyone could modify and adapt it. Obviously mentioning and giving credit to the original file. The "OsBlade" file has a safety pin that also works as support so no fool thinks it's a real weapon. It's Not... It's your problem if you remove it. (You know how paranoic people might be)

Based and inspired by Chris "Ammnra" Myles' Connor Hidden blade Prop.

ESPAÑOL:

Un diseño modernizado de la Hoja Oculta de Assassin's Creed III concebido principalmente para Cosplay. Fuente Libre/Abierta para que cualquiera lo pueda modificar y adaptar. Obviamente mencionando y dando credito al archivo original. El archivo "OsBlade" tiene un "Pin" de seguridad que funciona tambien como soporte para que ningun tonto piense que se trata de un arma de verdad. No lo es... Es tu problema si lo quitas. (Ya saben cuán paranóica puede ser la gente)

Basado e Inspirado en la Connor Hidden Blade Prop de Chris "Ammnra" Myles

FlashForge

Dreamer

Yes

  • 50%

ENGLISH:
You still might need to sand a bit.

ESPAÑOL:
Puede que necesites lijar un poco.

Additional Materials / Materiales adicionales

ESPAÑOL

  • Lija (de ser necesario ya que el diseño esta pensado para salir directo de la Impresora 3D)

  • Pegamento

  • Imanes.

  • Ligas/Bandas elásticas (de preferencia las que usan los dentistas. No temas pedirle a tu dentista que te regale/venda unas cuantas)

  • Clips o palillos dentales (lo que quepa en los agujeros)

ENGLISH:

  • sandpaper (if needed, because the design was thought to get out directly from 3D printing)

  • glue

  • Magnets

  • Rubber bands (preferentially those used by dentists. Don't be afraid of asking your dentist to sell/give you some)

  • Clips or Toothpicks (whatever fits in the holes)

title: Logitech C270 webcam Kossel XL 2020 front mount

description.text:
This is a Logitech C270 webcam mount for 2020x3 aluminum profile, designed for a Kossel XL printer.

The webcam is approximately a 10cm distance from the printer, 5cm higher than the bed. It's perfect to view a full bed of 240cm diameter, if the webcam has a wide angle lens (170°). By defaut, this is not the case for this webcam, so you need to change the lens. Here is what I used.

  • To assemble the parts (arm in the braket), you'll need a M3x12 to M3x20 screw with a M3 nut.
  • To fix the webcam on the arm, you'll need a M3x30 (M3x35 works too) and a M3 nylstop nut.
  • To fix the bracket on the 2020 profile, you'll need at least 2x M3x10 screw and 2x t-nuts (or 3 of each, as there is 3 holes).

title: Tevo Tarantula extruder offset bracket, to use with MKS Short Mount

description.text:
This bracket remixes and matches this one : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2235171

It will allow the extruder(s) to be placed properly above the MKS board when it's offset.

The last picture shows how to attach dual extruders with one metal bracket reversed.
On the left extruder a pair of washers is placed between the bracket and the top aluminium part. No spacer is required for the bottom part.

This greatly helps to get a decent path for the filament.

Print laying on the side with supports everywhere.

Only 2 screws are actually required on the Tarantula frame, this let you channel the X and Z stepper cables un the 2040 slot. Nozzle power and sensor cable can be routed through the bracket.

author: beerman_uk

title: HO Scale Grain (or whatever) Processing Facility

description.text:
This is a HO scale processing facility, with attached distribution warehouse.. Could be used to process grain, or any other type of product. The warehouse building features a railside loading dock with 2 roller doors, and a truck loading dock with 3 roller doors, and truck bumpers on the dock. The headhouse atop the silos is one piece and printed as a single unit.I have included a raised floor for the warehouse, just to bring the interior floor to the level of the loading docks. However, if you assemble it with all the roller doors in the closed position, this floor is not necessary.
There are a LOT of parts to this building (86+). I haven't included a print of the finished building, as, although I have begun to print this out, I have run out of filament and can't complete it yet.
This is a large building, and will take several days to print out. I have designed it so that all the pieces will fit on a 200 x 200 print bed. The original, that I built out of cardbaord, was even bigger (last photo) :)
Special care is needed for certain parts, so please read the printing instructions also.
Locos, track, etc shown in concept design.jpg, is NOT included. :)
The walls have been designed with 45deg angled edges to fit seamlessly together...however, if you feel the corner joins are still too obvious, you can always glue some L styrene onto the corners.
Please note the attribution license - NON commercial use, please.

Printer:

Anet A8 prusa clone

Resolution:

varies

Infill:

varies

Notes:

Most of the larger pieces can be printed at .2-.25 resolution, but I highly recommend printing the smaller detail parts at .1-.15 resolution.
I recommend printing the large flat pieces with a 20 -25% infill. and the smaller pieces (dust extractors, roof vents, utility boxes, alarm, etc) with 100% infill, for the sake of strength.
I also recommend (for the large flat pieces) printing at a minimum extruder temp of 205, 220-225 would be even better for the sake of good layer adhesion. I usually print at 200deg, but found when prying the large flat pieces of the print bed, that twisting can result in layer separation. Printing at a higher temp fixed this.
For the silos, you can print them (4hrs PER SILO) or just use some PVC pipe of the appropriate diameter.
For the piping that runs from the truck loading bay to the silos, I have not included an stl file, as this is best made just using a piece of styrene tube and bending accordingly.

Don't Own a 3D printer?

Don't own a 3D printer? Or don't want to print this out yourself? It is available printed from my website. (Assembly required).
http://scalemodelprints.com/store/?pd=31
Use the code IMATHINGIFAN at checkout to get a 25% discount.

description.text: CTC - Wall Bed 3D

Made it a little bigger and it now holds my 13ft jumper cables. My jumper cables are 20mm wide and 10mm thick. It could probably be a little bigger, but it works well enough for me. Now my jumper cables are just floating around in my trunk and tying up everything else!

I needed a modular and stackable sortiment box for my electronics, but couldn't find anything that fitted my needs. So I designed these.
The small Box is for standard 3D printers, and the big Box is for cheaper 3D Printers with a lower printing accuracy.
The inner part of the box fits both boxes, and was designed to have place for regular resistors. It features a place to put labeling and has a handle for easier use.

This version is substantially longer and taller than the original as well (90mm X 80mm from the bed).

Plate for the 3D Anet A8 printer.
Drawing by P.Bouchon for MaTeam3D (Facebook group - Ma Team 3D). https://www.facebook.com/groups/258346991299293/?ref=bookmarks
This plate replaces the H of the original Hotbed. It's made to stiffen the support of the hotbed which sometimes deforms when adjusting the height of the bed. The deformation can affect the bearings. This part can be made in plexi, aluminum PLA, ABS. Vesrion 8mm, 6mm and laser cut.
There is also an outgrowth on the side to fix a cable chain

Free use and modification

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Case for the DP30V5A power supply
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have the cheap and very handy DP30V5A power supply, and needed a case for it. I saw some of the other cases here but I wanted a barrel jack for the input and USB and XT60 for the output, so I can connect various other types of connectors.

I don't have the final USB and XT60 connectors yet, so I only ballparked them, but the holes should be good, pretty snug but not too hard to fit. The PSU itself fits great, and I will upload any changes I make as I print the final thing.

The XT60 connector is meant both for charging batteries and as a general-purpose connector (for example, I use it to get single wires for my breadboards, a DC barrel jack, etc). I didn't want to add a second barrel jack because I didn't want people accidentally plugging a power supply into the output and frying the DP.

It should print well with minimal supports, depending on how good your printer is at bridging. Mainly where it needs supports is the little insets for the connectors, which I added to prevent the connectors from moving left and right. The PSU fits very well without needing any glue, as it will always get pushed and never pulled, but you may want to superglue the connectors themselves to the case, just so you can pull and push them with reckless abandon.

Wanhao

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Doesn't Matter

Print them as I've provided them, i.e. face down, for best results. Infill should be 20% as you want some strength against pushing/pulling, and supports should only be needed on the inside of the case, where the USB, XT and USB connectors overhang.

remixed_from.title: Makerbot Replicator 2 end-stop switch spring replacement

title: A Thicker Makerbot Replicator 2 end-stop switch spring replacement

description.text:
Many thanks to DexCisco for making this mod for my machine easy by including an openscad file in his thing. :D

I managed to rip that little spring arm off the first month I owned the machine when some filament came off the spool and slapped against it, hooking the little arm and throwing it who knows where in the room. I never did find it. For the past 5 years I have just had a bit of waste print taped in front of the little button that occasionally fails and needs retaped.

I made a bunch of mods to my machine the past couple of weeks and looking through the list for replicator 2 things, I came across this mod. I tried it and my machine didn't hit the switch, just making a horrible noise. That is when I remembered a little note that was part of the fan duct mod saying to tape a little printed block to the side of the feed motor.

I use a different air cooler that wraps around the bottom, which means it actually hits before the standard stopping place, so I had to thicken the front of the spring arm to stop my machine from making a horrible noise. I included this duct in my list of remixes, if you want to check it out.

And it worked! I printed a few degrees hotter than normal to make the plastic stick together a little better because of the small little bits sticking up.

This mask isn´t wearable without a few modifications.
After I scaled the mask to lifesize the walls were 3/4" thick and I had to delete the needless 2 or 3 shells inside the mask to make it wearable anyway. The proportions don´t look good for me because the bat ears are oversized and to far behind. I shortened the ears and cut off a piece from the middle to bring the ears forward without resizing the face. I also added an extra part on the chin to have a better look.
The actual problem is that the neck hole is to small to fit the head through. At this point I have to choose if I make a piece from the back of the head or the chin removeable or if I have to make a mold and cast the mask with PU rubber or latex.

description.text:
I always felt that an axial fan was not a good solution for cooling my E3D V6 and none of the available radial fan adapters appealed to me. Most were just a mix and match collection of adapters that were ugly and positioned my fan poorly. So I came up with this. It keeps the mass close to the extruder and X-Axis to minimize shake induced vibration while drastically improving air flow to the hot-end heat sink. It prints as a single piece that fits firmly in place over your extruder, all you will need is a 5015 blower and 2 M3 mounting screws. Assembly is as easy as sliding it over your hot-end and mounting your fan.

I printed this in PETG with supports from the build surface only, the print should be oriented so that all airflow paths are horizontal during the printing process. There is some bridging involved but it printed well for me on the first go.

description.text:
https://youtu.be/KB_mjkMsW0k

ENGLISH (en français plus bas)
I designed this lock based on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2058932 which contained a very helpful video. Thank you for sharing your design!

I made it to be used as a large workable demo model in class, and made it look like the locks our students use for their own lockers. When the right combination is dialed in, the U-bar retracts and rotates so it can be put on any object.

Each rotor contains 25 holes so that the lock combination can be modified via moveable rotor screws that can be put in a multitude of configurations.

All important design parts were printed in a different color to facilitate explanation of its workings to my students.

Size when built: 240mm x 160mm x 114mm

This is my first published work, so any feedback is appreciated. Thank you.

FRANÇAIS
Je vous présente mon tout premier désign, d'après https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2058932 qui comportait un vidéo très utile, merci!

Le but était de produire à une plus grande échelle un modèle fonctionnel de démonstration des cadenas utilisés par les étudiants de mon école (ESC Cité des Jeunes). Lorsque la bonne combinaison est entrée, la barre en U se rétracte et pivote, permettant d'utiliser le cadenas sur une multitude de gros objets.

Chacun des 3 disques comporte 25 trous afin de pouvoir repositionner les 4 vis, modifiant la combinaison comme bon vous semble.

Chaque partie importante du désign a été imprimée d'une couleur différente afin d'aider avec l'explication de son fonctionnement, auprès de mes élèves.

Grandeur finale: 240mm x 160mm x 114mm

Ceci représente ma première oeuvre disponible au grand public. Je vous remercie à l'avance pour toute rétroaction. :)

comments.text: Okay, 5 hours later it is finished printing. Because I did not want to be printing tons of support material, I flipped the object on the Z-axis in Slic3r to put the big side of the object face down on the bed, like your orange colored print picture. I did not realise that this operation actually mirror imaged the object, which effectively made mine a left side mount bracket instead of the normal right side mount bracket. Luckily, it looks like everything works out okay after moving things around to the left side.

author: O3D

description.text:
I was inspired to make up something really quick.

Print flat, no need for supports.

Simple measurement tool. To show you if there is an electrostatic charge.
The LED shows what’s the sign of the charge.
The meter is very sensitive. At a decimeter distance, a charge is detected

You can download English or Dutch version of the front.

Printer:

Metaquip

Notes:

I use Lasercutter and 3 mm acrylic for the front.
Enclosure I bought at the local shop Okaphone.
The Hammond 1591B enclosure fit exact.

Explanation is in Dutch language.
But look and you'll easy to understand the possibilities of the meter.
The circuit is based on Thomas Kim design. (Google his name on Youtube)
Adjustable to fit any size of spool, you will need to print two of the clips and four of the stands. You will also need four M4 screws, 8x 608 skate bearings, and some 5mm or 3/16" rod.

Original design comes from http://koi29.info/solidworksF-vilebrequin.html It's a tution for solidworks. Part is for a Nissan 2.2 D
I found several stl files on grabcad

I designed the stand to look good on a desk but mainly to show to my students that all the central cylinders are contributing to the same rotating pair.
Therefore they must be toleranced as a whole so it is a good an easy way to understand example of common zone tolerancing

In dec'17 I changed the file for the stand as I have redesigned the cylindres for them to lock around the crankshaft better

Enjoy

Please post your makes

I wanted to make a spinner for my kids, 9 and 6. But the "normal" ones seemed a little to big for their hands. So I made this, a little smaller one. I use a 13x5x4 ball bearings and some M8 nuts and this was the result. Works pretty good. I printed in PLA at .2 layer height

This is an Turtle fidget Spinner I designed. It is designed to be on the smaller side so it should fit in kids hands, but adults can play with it too!

title: 38mm diameter filament spool bracket for replicator

description.text: you may found somthing on line supply the filament spool does not fit into makerbot original bracket. because makerbot one is 50mm and most china made standard is 38mm center hole diameter. you can use this while using the small hole spool thn.

1) Make sure the exterrior support has been choose when building Gcode
2) Set the In-Fill as much as possible, my one is 50%. more In-Fill cost more extruding time
3) A raft may necessary, my platform temperatue settings 110C
4) Make sure the filament no jam during extruding. because the extruding time is a bit long Remarks:
1) I found not everytime the output can be done without problems. I found the support materials does not strong to hold the product, sometimes the part may lossing out because the part not firmly sticking on the platform
2) Therefore, while the plastic up to the cylinder portion, try to use the kapton to help a bit (see the photo). then guarantee everytime the output can be done.

author: brianhomer

description.text: To celebrate the new Donkey Kong Tropical Freeze, here is a puzzle to pass the time while wait for it to come out. to put this together you must put them in the order they were uploaded, first take the first piece and the second piece and side the second one into the first one, then attach the third piece to the bottom of the second piece, then connect the fourth piece to the first and third piece (it should look like a large D in half a barrel) then take the fifth piece and attach to the side of the first piece, then take the sixth piece (the K like piece) and put the top of it in the fifth piece, then take the last piece and put on to the bottom of the sixth piece (it should look like a DK in a barrel now) enjoy and celebrate cranky kong back in action!!!!!

I created this add on Servo Door Opener for my Reflow Oven I built using the ControLeo2 controller.

You will need 6 #2X10 screws, 1 #0X5 screww (for pin) and 2 #3X12 bolts with washers and nuts for assembly.

I also added a front face panel for the BlackandDecker oven I used and buttons for the ControLeo2 control panel.

description.text:
This is the upper door clip for an Arrow shed. A set of these are $12 at the hardware store, or you can print this one for a few cents.

I printed mine at ABS 4 perimeters, 75% infill, and lubricated with white lithium grease. This configuration works and feels as durable as the original. PLA might work, but I am afraid that the screw might crack the plastic. The part is available in two formats. The "OEM" format is a very close reproduction of the original injection molded part. This part contains several thin filleted sections that are difficult to print and would be very weak as a printed part. The "Modified for Printing" version has these thin sections revised to print more easily. The parts we installed on the shed are the "Modified for Printing" revision.

I printed this with the round pips that stick out down, parallel to the print bed, matching the orientation of the Thingiverse render.

print_settings.Notes:: All ABS which has proven more than robust enough to take the punishment this frame has undergone so far.

description.text:
Another one of my own plays on the ZMR250 "lowrider" approach.

with this design I've Incorporated everything you'd possibly want on a 250 into the inside of a fully enclosed canopy while keeping everything clean cut and simple so even the most basic printer can cope with it, that doesn't mean to say its lacking in regards to capability.

my own frame has a full 1000tvl fpv setup with a 72ch 25/50/200mw switchable Vtx, full minimOSD or supersimpleOSD, CC3d Nano (but design can take any fc upto 35x35 (such as Naze, full sized CC3d etc), Matek PDB with 5v & 12v filtered becs, Flysky RS-R6b rx and a Lipo alarm all fitted internally with room to spare (If you prefer your FC and PDB in a stacked format there's even enough room for that)

There is two versions of the lower plate, one is a "clean" version which simply acts to enclose the lower half of the canopy and give landing feet to keep motors and arms away from the ground, the other incorporates a additional mounting point for a addressable led WS2812b board.

all additional hardware required is what comes supplied with the stock ZMR250 frame so no need to purchase bolting hardware etc.

overall weight of my own frame WITH 1800mah battery is 463g and with the 1800 battery I get a good 12mins of very hard flying.

current spec at time of publishing....

Eachine Vtx03
Eachine 1000Tvl cam
Supersimple OSD (with Rssi resistor mod)
CC3d Nano
FlySky RS-R6b RX
Matek PDB
LDPower 1806 2600kv
LDPower 10Amp esc

further planned upgrades

2305 2600kv motors
15/20amp esc

oops forgot to point out why the front has a slotted opening rather than just one for the cam lens, thats so a AIO fpv cam can be used (such as the Eachine TX01/02/03), the top slot is to allow the attached cloverleaf antenna to stick out, in addition it can also be used in conjunction with a smaller less powerful cam which can be tilted upward to the pilots preferred angle.

This is the new Star Trek Discovery Captain's Insignia. Magnets can be glued to the backplate and front so that it can be worn without any damage to clothing. That would also means it sticks to your dry-erase board or refrigerator! I used 5mm x 1mm magnets and gorilla glue.

The captain's insignia should be painted in gold.

I used the Star Trek Discovery most recent insignia from the Star Trek logo for the canvas in Fusion 360 to get the overall shape correct. I matched features for the Captain's insignia using screen captures from the most recent trailer at the time. The captain has 4 (raised) pips on the surface of the insignia, other ranks might actually have holes or combination of raised pips and holes.

remixed_from.author: Thorped
remixed_from.title: Modified Wanhao i3 fan duct designed

title: Failed?    Experimental axial front mount adapter for Thorped's Cooler

description.text:
Well, I think this design is a bust.
The printer works fine enough, but I don't really think there is a noticeable difference - axial fans probably just don't have enough power to move air that much around. (Not to forget the tiny holes where the parts connect.)

THIS IS EXPERIMENTAL!

Meaning, I just about finished printing the last part (again, after several attempts to get everything right) and am now screwing it to the printer and looking at it printing something very simple.

(That I printed everything in PLA doesn't help - I'm afraid it'll melt, but lets see if I have to break out the ABS again.)

While I am quite certain it won't do any harm, I take no responsibility if anything happens to your printer. Watch it while it prints, and have your hand near the off switch. (Personally, I've bought one of those neat "foot pedal" switches you plug between the printer and the wall socket - that way I can pound on it when I need to turn it off quickly without having to really aim :-)

See below for details.
(Sorry, the habit to put up walls of text is hard to break.)

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

as little as possible

Notes:

I think none of MY parts needs to be ABS, but the actual cooler probably should be.

Use little infill, the lighter it is, the better.

For reference, the original Wanhao shroud (made of metal) weighs about 30grams.
My printed (and partially screwed) adapter+shroud+cooler weighs about 35grams.

Since I've often read that the metal holding the fan is weak (can't confirm, so far - maybe I'm lucky?), I've tried to shave off as much dead weight as possible.

You need a few screws, of course. About 14mm M3, I think. Just try whatever fits, there is no threading in there.

I'm not certain if it's a problem or not, but maybe you should try to close the gaps where the parts meet. (Using some sort of putty? Or redesign the shroud, see fruther below.)

What is it and why:

I really like Thorped's cooler - especially the remix of dumbcomputers which looks more fluent to me (no idea if it actually is any better).

However, I had two problems with it:
1) it's back-mounted
2) it uses a radial fan

My printer is facing away from me, so I wanted a front-mount. After all, the original shroud is there as well.

I'm unable to find a fitting radial fan (those I can easily get don't have female connectors).

So I first designed the adapter to mount the cooler to the chassis provided by Wanhao, then adapted it further to connect to a modified fan shroud (taken from tinours95130's remix).

The reason why it's in separate pieces (instead of, say, redesign the whole cooler to incorporate at least the adapter, or combine the adapter with the shroud) is that this way it should be easier to switch parts out.
For example if you'd want to use a bigger fan shroud, you can keep everything else and just redesign that.
Or if you already have Thorped's cooler and want to try this design, you don't have to reprint the cooler - which is the one part that probably should be ABS or something heat resistant.

Problems with the design

1) the weight
The original fan shroud weighs 30 grams (without fan), so ideally this should be less, especially if you're using a bigger fan.
I removed as much as seemed reasonable, though my limited skills (there's a reason I'm using 3d building blocks - aka Tinkercad :-) didn't let me do everything I imagined.
The fan shroud probably can still lose some weight. There's a few bugs inherent in this design, I think, but I wasn't able to fix them.
I've shaved off a few milimeter on the sides and from the top, which means the screws have less grip.

2) unintended holes
Since the fan shroud is plugged into the original cooler design, I tried to emulate the knobs of a radial fan, to plug those holes.
I'm afraid I rather failed at that. Maybe I should pull up a wall on the inside? I.e. have the knobs on the outside, to secure it, but have a short wall move on inside, to keep air from getting out.
There's a reason this is both work-in-progress and experimental :-)

3) the HEIGHT and angle
I've used dumbcomputers' remix to model the angle of the adapter - and a lot of guesswork as well. Being mounted, it looks fine to me - the nozzle is a bit lower than the fan shroud, that seems good.
But, it's just guessing - so maybe there is a problem that should be fixed.

4) the weight again, and the mounting
Somehow the original fan shroud screws don't seem to have as much grip as they should. The holes are all 3mm, but maybe the top holes need to be smaller? Or I could just use other screws, I guess.
If the metal really is weak, it might bend over time. Maybe a secondary mounting would be wise? Perhaps a snap-in bracket that attaches to the motor?

5) more?
Any other problems I'm not seeing? Go ahead, tell me. I promise I'll read.

Untested V2

I have redesigned the fan shroud to have less angle so the air should flow smoother.
I've also shortened the actual shroud and shaved off more from the sides.
I also made the adapter smaller so it'll weigh less. I think two screws will be enough, maybe it could even be reduced to one screw.

However, neither is tested - not even successfully printed yet - the new design is much steeper and printing it upside down (to make sure the screw-holes are straight), causes problems with the connector :-/
Also, the thin plane at the end of the connector is hard to print - this should be fixed somehow.
Maybe it can be removed altogether? It's there to make sure the air can't flow back.

Adapter Readjusted

After I realized that the entire cooler was skewed due to the belt holder screws moving the motor (bending the plates), I had to readjust the adapter. It's shorter and the top screwholes are moved, so that the actual cooler doesn't touch the heat block.

However, this still isn't right - it would need some more adjusting, I think it should be a bit shorter and instead thicker, to move the cooler further away from the heat block.

Feel free to experiment, but as the title now says, I consider this design failed. I fear if I continue, I'd be trying to make a circle even rounder, to finally get it into the square hole...
I need to restart, try a different approach.

title: 3DR Solo Mini M8N / BN-800 GPS Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Overview:

This is a bracket for the 3DR Solo to allow mounting a Banggood M8N which can be purchased for under $18, or a ReadytoFlyQuads M8N Mini8 which is currently on sale for $17.
This bracket keeps the GPS closer to the top (same as stock GPS position) in an effort to keep the antenna a little more in the clear. The GPS is mounted to the top side of the bracket with three very short screws or double stick tape. The GPS - with bracket attached - is then flipped over and mounted in the Solo with the original screws (use only three). The original copper shield should then be re-installed. One screw can be inserted through the copper shield - use tape if you need to secure the shield on the other side.

Wiring:

The two GPS's linked above will work out of the box with the 3DR Solo. The baud rate is already correct. The only thing you need to do is splice the harness that comes with the new GPS into the stock Solo GPS harness. The wiring colors on the harness that comes with the new M8N GPS will probably vary, so you will have to verify the connections. These GPS's come with 6 wires, but you only need 4. You need Vcc (5V) - typically RED, Ground - Typically BLACK, Transmit - typically YELLOW, and Receive, typically gray or brown.

If you did everything right, you should get much faster satellite acquisition times with the new GPS. 16 satellites on the ground and 20+ in the air is common. I have seen as many as 23. You should be getting HDOP's of 0.5 to 0.7.

Be aware that although aquisition times are faster and HDOP values are improved, the robustness of the GPS lock with the above GPS's may or not be better than stock. As with any GPS, be prepared for loss of GPS lock if you enter a location where a large portion of the sky is suddenly blocked by trees or buildings. You can have over a dozen satellites showing and loose GPS lock due to multipath interference. Always have Manual mode programmed onto your A or B button and know how to fly manually without GPS.

comments.text: Thanks for this!  I had already ordered a BN-800 for one of my Solos and was going to mod the board to fit the screws.  With this I don't need to change anything except the wiring.

description.text:
I made this model by request of one good person, Ryan D Hoke. Are here what he said:

This character is a mascot for a rare disease research group, Castleman Disease Collabrative Network. He is a warrior. His helmet is in the form of a Castle Wall tower and he wears Knight armour. He resembles a the strength and courage to fight against the Castleman's Disease.

Castleman's Disease is a rare and deadly illness which is caused by the bodies immune system. The immune system attacks the body and organs of the patient. This disease is deadlier than all cancers combined and is common as ALS (Remeber all the ice bucket challenges.) This Castleman Warrior is a reminder to all patients and their loved ones what it is like to be strong and fight with the hopes of finding a cure. To find out more about this disease and help find a cure check out CDCN.org and visit Castleman Warriors to see some of the Castleman Warriors helping to bring awareness to this deadly disease.

I spent several nights to do this model, so please, spend a few minutes and visit the Castleman Warriors web page above. Thanks a lot!

And as usual - print it, share it, enjoy it!

PS: you may ask why knight have no sword and where you can get it? Easy - a lot of the swords are available on the Thingiverse, so choose any you like. Just play with it size to fit the knight hand.

Update 2017-06-11:

Model in pose was fixed, re-download please.
(filename: CastlemanWarriorMascot_combinedInPose_fixed.stl)

Update 2017-06-12:

I found an issue with the shield handle - it is too big (zero tolerance), and almost impossible to put inside hole in the shield. Sorry, that was my fault, I did not apply tolerance correction on it after latest changes. Please scale it down the handle a little (from 100% to 96-94%) meanwhile, and I will fix the model when I will have a chance.

Update 2017-06-13:

Shield handle size/tolerance fixed.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Model should be printed with the supports! I made another, a sliced version (filename: CastlemanWarriorMascot_FULL_SET_sliced.stl) of it, for easier printing, but it may need supports in some places anyway.
So choose what you like more but I would recommend to print usual, not-sliced version by default (filename: CastlemanWarriorMascot_FULL_SET.stl).

Print the included tolerance test (filename:
CastlemanWarriorMascot_TOLERANCE_TEST.stl) at first - details should not fit too tights or too freely. Adjust print settings if needed.

Use drop of glue to fix the shield handle, that is necessary.

title: Chevrolet LT1 Water Pump Seal Tool (J39089)

description.text:
Water pump seals on the LT1 V8 engine are extremely difficult to install correctly without the J39089 tool. I was without one, but I had a few minutes so I whipped my own version up in solidworks. My first version fit a little snug, so this v2 is made slightly larger ID. Since my first one worked I've already got the engine assembled before making the changes to the design so this version is untested. It should be a perfect fit.

Print settings shouldn't matter much, print in the default orientation (narrow end down) no supports needed. Probably wise to use a brim as the bottom is rather small in surface area.

V Slot to 4545 BR aluminium profile (10 slot). This is an alternative motor to attach to the pillar drill head that i will upload next. The nuts and bolts are listed on the drawing. There is a slight circular movement because each item is fixed on one end. This is easy to correct by using a glue gun on the rounded corner/join. The glue is easy to remove with a knife.

I am preparing to build the OpenRC F1 car and needed a place to keep all the small parts. I couldn't find anything that appealed to me so I designed my own. Each square is 25mm with filets all around to make getting things out easier. There is one longer area for the parts bigger than 25mm. Overall height is 5mm and each square/rectangle is 3mm deep.

I designed it in Fusion 360.

Here is a link to the Fusion 360 drawing: http://a360.co/2rY6t29

Update 11Jun2017 - I added an STL of one of my earlier versions that is just a 4x3 grid of the 25mm boxes.

D Moews sent me a program that calculates recursive curves. It extends the program included with thing:2363723 - Torus Knots. Many of the curves are knots. Here are four knots generated by the program. Knot 1 is a trefoil.

The fortran souce code and the input parameters for the construction of the four knots are included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Here is D Moews' explanation of how the program works - it's a comment prefixed to the program.

Starting with a circle traversed a number of times, this program repeatedly changes a curve into a generalized helix wrapped around itself by calculating the TNB frame based on the curve and then offsetting the curve by a vector in the NB plane which, as one's point of view moves along the curve, rotates around the origin in the NB plane a specified number of times with a given phase offset.

After generation and translation, the final curve is enclosed in a circular cylinder with specified radius, and a triangular mesh is created, sampling the surface with NCVPTS points along the curve and NCYPTS points around the cylinder. The mesh is then written to a specified output file in STL format.
Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

description.text:
This was made with 45 BR aluminium profile 400mm long for the base, 475mm for the vertical length. The Drill vice is adjustable left,right by the use of 6mm studding. This size is used because it is 1mm per turn. The two 6mm nuts in the vice base for adjustment and stability. I have used two nuts in both the Rotary base and Milling base for the same reason.
It could also be adjusted forward/back by using a set up similar to the indexing adjustment.

The Vertical length is fixed using 45mm wide timber brackets, also the drill motor. These are fixed using 10mm bolts (20mm long).

There are three different handles included, the one with the holes is for long bolts or shaft if wanted. The rack has two types, one for T slide nuts and the other using standard 4mm bolts with washers.

The T-nut/wing bolt is used as a temporary drill stop. Some of the drawings look slightly different because things are added/changed all the time.

Text files with a detailed parts/assembly list will be uploaded tomorrow.

description.text:
Add a personalized touch to any picture or document frame. This one features two badges that clamp onto a picture frame. It is for a friend entering retirement.

The 3 part assembly features a badge, a clamp and a pin. The frame clamp retains an 8-32 nut. There are 4 files to choose from having different gaps for your frame: 1/2 in, 3/4 in, 1 in and 1-1/4 in. The pin tack holds the badge and the clamp together. The pin tack is a modification of whpthomas' design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:130879 The badge is a 3-1/2" x 2-3/8" oval using Google's Courgette font.

The second badge with the text "mon ami Paul" uses the icon 'Retired' by Lemon Liu from the Noun Project, https://thenounproject.com/

remixed_from.author: mike_mattala
remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

description.text:
I've made iPhone Mounts for both telescopes and microscopes in the past. Each of these required me to remove my case first before I could use them. I decided to try to make a mount that wouldn't require this. It was also important to me to make one mount that I could use on either a telescope or a microscope.

I don't know how universal this mount actually is, but I do know it will fit an iPhone 5 or 6 either with or without a case. There's a lot of room for adjustment, so I'm sure it will also work with many other phones as well. It also fits our school's compound and dissecting microscopes as well as out telescopes.

When using this it is important to keep some distance between the phone camera and the scope eyepiece. The only way to avoid vignetting is to use the digital zoom on your phone. For optimal field of view make sure your vignetting circle has crisp edges.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Notes:

The screws on the phone holder portion were printed with 6 perimeters for strength. I could have just used a high infill. However I didn't need the knobs to be solid. With 6 perimeters the screw part is pretty solid.

Everything else was printed at 10% infill with only 3 perimeters. Only the "Clamp Clip" requires any support.

The screws on the phone mount were made in OpenSCAD using Nut_Job by mike_matta. I took the long screw into Tinkercad to make the smooth shaft portion wider. Some of the scope mount came from G-Clamp by johann517. One of these days I will learn how to make my own threaded parts, but until then I'm sure I will continue to rely on both of these.

All the rest was designed in Autodesk Fusion360. This was the first project I've made in this program, so there was a lot of learning going on.

This was printed with PETG. The phone holder bends a little when tightened. Printing in PLA might help mitigate this, but I haven't tried that to know for sure. This is actually my fifth version of the phone holder. The bend is small enough now that it doesn't overly annoy me, so I think I'm done.

comments.text: Interesting, your is at 5000 steps, I have to have mine set to 13000 to get the extruder correct. Is your board set to 1/32 or 1/16 stepping ?
comments.author: thystonius

comments.text:
It is set to 1/32.
I was really perplexed about this too because according to the Zesty doc it should be at 6000. "Start with 3000 steps/mm with a 1.8 deg stepper and 1/16 microstepping" So i started with 6000 and then measured as they suggested. It doesn't seem to make any sense. Is it possible you have one of the 0.9deg steppers?
comments.author: Jarery

comments.text: Turns out i had forgotten to turned off Volumetric Extraction for using the Octoprint Control area to manually extract, so mine was 2.4 x normal. So using that factor I'll be in the 5000 to 5400 range, similar to you. All other items I have set as recommended by them in their setup page. 120 accell, 30 retract with 1.2mm firmware retraction, 0.5A on the stepper. I have not messed with the Junction_Deviation.
comments.author: thystonius

comments.text: Glad there is an explanation, i was starting to second guess what I had done.  My retraction is about the same (I was down at 1.1 was last used), but I was still getting some stringing so I was going to increase my non-print moves to 100mm/s and I think that will really help.

Keep in mind these will warp if you use black PLA - I'd suggest using ABS if possible or using white filament and painting a light color. I painted my PLA ones silver and they don't seem to warp in the tropical sun here in Hawaii. You can install them either 'lip up' or 'lip down' and I'd suggest using either rivets or stainless self tapping screws and 3M tape.
I went with 20% infill to give a nice look on the car.

Probably won't make you go faster but it sure will feel like it.

As for the endpiece - I had a print of the main part that ran out of filament after the "spacer" portion was 56mm wide - so I created a mirror-image piece that has the spacer on the other side and is 39mm wide to make the total 95mm spacing -same as the other pieces. Just print one of these to make the left-hand end of the diffuser.

In conclusion you should print 4 entire diffuser pieces, then a fifth one you stop after the spacer is 56mm wide, and then one of the endpieces to make a 6 strake diffuser.

title: Phantom 4 Bat Cooler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I bought my DJI Phantom 4 Pro drone and love it! I even bought 2 extra batteries and the 3 port DJI charging station so I'd always have a charged battery and others charging. Well the one thing with it is that with any LiPo battery that during high discharge the pack gets hot (No not like exploding hot) and when you're ready to throw it on the charger you have to wait for it to cool off before it will charge (the battery is so smart it won't even accept a charge until it cools down enough to charge it safely). A major improvement on the Phantom 4 batteries compared to the Phantom 3 batteries is that there are air cooling channels between the LiPo cells allowing faster cooling and also to reduce heat transferred between cells. Well I saw this and thought "Now if I could blow cool air thru these it would cool off faster!" And POOF the idea and final design of the Bat Cooler came to be!
I used a small computer CPU cooling fan I had laying around and cut the JST power plug off it and soldered on a female barrel power connector so I could use a standard 12 VDC wall power supply to power it. I haven't installed a safety screen on it because it is so small I really don't think it needs it. The internal fan diameter is 67.85mm so I'm not sure what that makes the total "Fan Size", the side to side measurement of the fan is 72mm square. The fan is set to blow inwards, in other words the airflow is thru the fan, thru the battery, and out the oval exhaust ports.

One side of the end of the battery has more of a hangover then the other side does, this goes down into the fan enclosure and the shorter side goes into the side with the notch. You can see this in the pictures.

Side Note: If you make a 12 VDC power cord with either a cig lighter plug end or alligator clips on it you could use it with power from your car or truck.

If you like the design make sure to hit the LIKE button. If you print one share it with others by choosing I MADE ONE. And if you have a comment or question please feel free to leave it in the comments section!

Remove the inside supporting material, clean the exhaust ports (if your printer has an issue with stringing). I left a little "Wiggle Room" in the opening where you insert the battery so it fits nicely but won't bind when pulling the battery out, you many have to trim the opening depending on the final print on your printer.
I designed this with AutoDesk 123D Design and printed it on my FlashForge Creator Pro using Simplify3D (S3D).

description.text:
I had some spare acrylic from another project, so I decided to get this project underway. The basic idea is very similar to Alex Kuzmuk's design.
https://kukuruku.co/post/diy-an-astro-tracker-in-two-nights/

I desired a simple and reliable star tracker, that was also small enough to carry, particularly for hiking or travelling.

The use of the Arduino provides a lot of flexibility in gear and thread choice. Mine uses an M6 thread to drive the barn door.

You may need to adapt it to your tripod/camera mount. There's a 6.5mm (1/4) hole for the camera mount. I used a 3d printed base for a ball joint from an old monopod, bolted in with a 6mm bolt. The tripod mount is designed to fit my Vanguard tripod with foot dimensions of 10mm high, top 32.3mm square, base 42mm square.

There's a couple of potential improvements that could be made. The hinge could be redesigned to incorporate bearings (see update 19/06/17). The gear system could benefit from bearings as well. In a 'perfect' system, the main gear would rotate around a bearing, and the guide rod would be constrained by the gear. In this model (and most other barn door star trackers) the threaded rod constrains the main gear, and is itself constrained by the hole in the acrylic. As the hole in the perspex has to have some leeway for the threaded rod, this could result in vibration or oscillation as the rod and gear move around the hole.

This design includes a picatinny rail for mounting a sighting scope.

Electronics consists of an Arduino Nano (just the board - no riser pins), an illuminated switch, and a 5V BYJ48 stepper motor. Speed control is defined in the code, so just flick the switch to start tracking.
https://youtu.be/23A9o62kssQ

I'm not going to draw a sketch for the electronics. I'll just list the wiring below. There's not much clearance in the case for wiring, so be neat. :D
Pin 12 -> switch -> ground
Pin 3 -> stepper IN1
Pin 4 -> stepper IN2
pin 5 -> stepper IN3
pin 6 -> stepper IN4
5V -> stepper positive
Ground -> stepper negative
5V -> switch LED (If you want an illuminated switch)
ground -> switch LED (If you want an illuminated switch)

The whole thing is powered over USB from a battery pack. In my case I'm using a 4AA Goal Zero power pack.

Fasteners used were:
10 x M5 countersunk. I cut mine down to the right length, but if you have options, then lengths should be around 6x12mm (picatinny rail and hinge) and 4x 25mm (tripod mount).
2x ~3mm screws, ~15mm long (to screw the control box to the tripod mount).
6x #4x12mm screws (for Nano enclosure and control box lid).
2x 3mm bolts, ~ 15-20mm long (for motor).
1x M6 bolt (for camera mount)
1x M6 threaded rod.

In terms of weight capability, the main factor is probably the acrylic panels and plastic rather than the gearing. I don't see any problems with mounting things up to 1.5KG on mine. If mounting heavier stuff, just be aware that the tripod and camera mount are plastic. In terms of gears, with a 5/1 gear ratio to the stepper and another ~3/1 in the barndoor, I suspect that there is no camera heavy enough to could stop the gears from turning.

Warning: Yes, you can rotate your camera around to tip it over the hinge. If you're concerned then figure out your balance point and cut the threaded rod a bit shorter than that.

Update: 19/6/2017
I have now developed a bearing hinge that uses a couple of 608 bearings (Roller skate bearings). The files for the bearing hinge are "Bearing Hinge Interior" and "Bearing Hinge Exterior". The bearings are clamped in place with a couple of M8 35mm bolts, with captive nuts in the Interior portion. There's 1mm clearance between the two sections, so make sure you don't overtighten the bolts. This design means that all of the bearings are captive, rather than just relying on a push-fit, and can centre the hinge components so that there is no rubbing anywhere between plastic.

Notes:

Hinges are designed to print in place (print with pin axis vertical). There are two tolerances of hinge available - 0.3 and 0.4mm. If possible I'd use the 0.3mm tolerance hinge, as it also has thicker top plates.

Many of these are structural pieces, so I'd go heavy, rather than light on infill and wall thickness.

There are gear designs available in both the panels layout (for laser cutting) and the 3D printing files (for printing). Use whichever you prefer. Hopefully I've got the offsets all correct. :D

Arduino Code

Arduino code.

#include<AccelStepper.h>
#define HALFSTEP 8
#define motorPin1  3     // IN1 on the ULN2003 driver 1
#define motorPin2  4     // IN2 on the ULN2003 driver 1
#define motorPin3  5     // IN3 on the ULN2003 driver 1
#define motorPin4  6     // IN4 on the ULN2003 driver 1

AccelStepper stepper1(HALFSTEP, motorPin1, motorPin3, motorPin2, motorPin4);

int buttonmode = 2;
boolean Motortoggle = 0;
const int SwitchPin = 12;     // the number of the pushbutton pin
const int ledPin =  13;      // the number of the LED pin
// variables will change:
int Switchstate = 0;         // variable for reading the pushbutton status

void setup() {
Serial.begin(9600);

  stepper1.setMaxSpeed(261.41);
  stepper1.setAcceleration(50.0);
  stepper1.setSpeed(261.41);
  //stepper1.moveTo(20000);
  // initialize the LED pin as an output:
  pinMode(SwitchPin, INPUT_PULLUP);
  pinMode(ledPin, OUTPUT);
  // initialize the pushbutton pin as an input:
  digitalWrite(SwitchPin, HIGH);
}

void loop() {
  // read the state of the switch value:
  Switchstate = digitalRead(SwitchPin);
  if (Switchstate == LOW) {
stepper1.runSpeed();
digitalWrite(ledPin, HIGH);
} else {
 stepper1.stop();
 digitalWrite(ledPin, LOW);
}
}

description.text:
Hi, welcome to my first ever 3d model!

This mini dock uses the original dock's docking guidance to prevents damaging your console's USB port. It also has openings for the air vents behind the console for air intake.

You will need the original electronics, the base of the USB port, 4 silver and 4 black screws or 8 silver screws from the original dock.

The text-based assembly instructions are below, you can refer to the images above:

  1. Connect USB ribbon and led cable to the board
  2. Insert the LED into the slot on the base of the dock so the LED lines up with the opening
  3. Slide the board into the base and secure with 4 silver screws
  4. Insert the base of the USB port into the 4 pillars in the dock
  5. Insert the springs, the guidance to the USB port base
  6. Close up the dock by lining up the locking mechanism and the screw holes, sealed everything off with 4 silver or black screws

Enjoy my first creation!

title: Support-less Cube Stress Test
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Not support-less, support free.

Tested on cupcake with gearmotor extruder. Acetone before cleaning support material -- layers would otherwise be too fragile. Newer machines may fair better.
Use a raft and disable heating after the first couple layers. This object is top-heavy and will not stay upright on its own. If you use a heated build platform, the first layers will remain soft, which will allow enough wobble to disrupt the upper portion of the print.

title: Walking stick holder for a wall or a wheelchair

description.text:
Make a convenient and secure walking stick/cane holder for a wheelchair or wall
mount. Once printed and assembled, attach it to the wheelchair with velcro
tape, or use bolt holes for more permanent mounting to wheelchair or a wall.

Before printing, please check diameter of the walking cane. This design was
tuned specificly for "HurryCane" folding cane. If you use a different cane,
just measure its diameter, subtract couple millimeters and change values in
WalkingStickHolder.scad. Once you do that, you'll need to regenerate
WalkingStickHolder_Part1.stl in OpenSCAD.

The assembly is simple - take Part2 and insert it into the hole of Part1, then
slide Part3 onto the end of Part1 until it clicks.

You may want to consider printing two of these holders if you use non-folding
cane.

Enjoy!

title: Spool Cover Box Corner Brackets for Lack Enclosures
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cats.

They love things that move. They love to break stuff. They love to play with skinny string-like objects. Like spools of filament.

So when we put our printer in a Lack Enclosure (Which is an awesome thing, by the way), we decided we also needed to protect the spool and filament going in.

One Eket "Cabinet" from Ikea ($15-$20 depending on size at the time of this writing) and some guiding corner holders later and we have a good solution. These are the corner holders. The will work for pretty much any box that should be set down onto something and kept from sliding around as long as they can be attached.

Two options, so don't print everything.

  • Option 1: Inner Corners. You can use the inner corners on the front, or the back, or both, or neither. The inner corners are much more difficult to position though.
  • Option 2: Outer corners. You can mix and match inner and outer corners. Outer corners are much easier to place with tight tolerance.

You can hold outer corner brackets in place against the box when screwing them down for the tightest tolerance and fit. The angle of all the brackets helps guide the box into place.

A tiny, tiny piece of putty or clay can be used to hold the inner brackets close to in position but slightly too far outwards and then slide the box over them very slowly to pull them in. Then take the box off very carefully and screw them down. You can measure for the inner corner brackets, however I found that the rounded corners of the boxes involved make that a challenge and even a millimeter of leeway will allow wiggle in the end result. Sub-millimeter fit is good in this.

Bonus points for air-tight filament system:

  • Use silicone caulk around the top (back) of the cabinet box and the inside corners edges to make it air-tight.
  • Use a silicone membrane with an tight hole for a bowden tube to feed through
  • Put an even bead of soft silicone caulk around the open side of the box and let it half-dry so its surface is dry, then place it on top to form fit.
  • Use a filament holder and/or bowden tube holder (even with a direct feed extruder) to feed the filament into the tube and down into the box through the silicone membrane. The bowden tube can still slip up and down through the membrane as the print head moves.
  • Some desiccant in the box and you're set.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

20-35%

Notes:

May need rotation for printing. Front Outer should be mirrored as well.

Extra Hardware

Between eight and ten #6 or #8 wood screws.

Do not try to superglue to a Lack table. It just REALLY doesn't work.

The Eket box is NOT quite truly square, so if you have tight tolerances in the placement of the corners, make sure you keep track of which side of the box is the front.

This is version two of a hinge I created so I could remove the door on my 3d printer as needed. This has been an awesome mod and I can't tell you how handy it is. I changed some measurements to better fit the bibo 2 touch as well as a better print but it does need to be printed with supports. Print as you see it. I stood the free side on its end so the layers would create a stronger hinge where it curves. Here is a video of how it works

https://youtu.be/g3DF_necFjg

I noticed the original models were to hold a 10mm wide LED strip. My strip was 8mm. I created a new mount strip based off original design to hold a double strip of 8mm.

The channel in the back for the mount clips has tight clearances to help hold your lighting in the direction you set it.

Each strip is 215mm long.

6/19/17 - I have noticed that this model is tight for the LED strip width. Until I can upload a new slightly wider model you should print this STL at a scale of about 103% to 105%. This will be enough to get the LEDs in easier, but not mess with the mounting hole on the back.

Used Fusion 360 to get measurements from the original then drafted up a new one for the smaller LED strip.
A few prototype sessions later and I am pleased with the turnout.

Comments welcome so I can improve the design.

description.text:
-STAR WARS DE-10 Blaster Pistol-
The DE-10 blaster pistol was a model of blaster pistol that saw use in the galaxy during the Galactic Civil War. Its heaviest users in the period were members of the Death Watch, a Mandalorian splinter group based on the Forest Moon of Endor at the time. When a spacer infiltrated the Death Watch bunker, their main base on the moon, sometime after the Battle of Yavin, the sentient discovered a schematic for the weapon along with specialized barrels used in its construction. The spacer eventually had one of the weapons created for personal use.
http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/DE-10_blaster_pistol

I am still learning how to use programs like SketchUp and the lot, so my skill is limited at the moment as of what I can do.

Notes:

  • Can now be printed with NO Supports!*
  • The .stl files aren't replica scale, but the full size for replica is 200.00 x 198.46 x 20.45 for each of the new files (3halfs and 3halfs mirrored) prints.
  • Finished Full Scale Replica is 15'x7' and if you are making this for a child the size is 13'x6'.

*supports not needed for the 3halfs and 3halfs mirrored.

Printer:

XYZPrinting Da Vinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:
  • Printed with Hatchbox PLA.
  • This needs to be glued together. I used Original Gorilla Glue, the foam it creates can fill any gaps nicely so no filler would be needed. Scrape away the foam with a razor while it's mid way through the hardening stage. If you're having trouble with any gaps due to warping you can use Loctite repair putty all purpose. For the putty, also scrape away excess with a razor while it's semi-hard.
  • The 3Halfs and 3Halfs Mirrored can now be printed with NO supports without any issues!
  • For full scale replica print 3Halfs.stl and 3HalfsMirrored.stl at 200.00 x 198.46 x 20.45.
  • Print time is around 1560 minutes based on my print settings (without rafts).

This is a remix of the glue spatula. I used 3D-Coat to cut the teeth at the end, made it thicker and added the podcast title along with a hole to hang it on a hook nearby your SLA 3D Printer. It is designed for use with DUP SLA machines such as the Duplicator 7 from Wanhao. However, I made it on my Raise3D N2 FDM machine. I use it to sift through the resin before and after every print to mix up the resin as well as remove cured pieces.
To learn more about this thing as well as a heck of a lot more stuff related to all aspects of 3D Printing, 3D Design and 3D Capture check out our podcast! It's FREE and still has no advertisements.

comments.text: I never got this to print on any of the newer machines -- I don't know why. It seems to print well on cupcakes and MK4 extruder. Print with the plastic as cold as possible. Keep the thickness intermediate -- good layer adhesion but don't make the filament squish too much. I use a raft to hold it down, it is top heavy. I don't use any heat on the build platform -- it makes the bottom soft which disrupts printing once it becomes more top-heavy.

Hi. I own a Anet A6. I saw during assembly that the structure was not in perfect squad.
Now that I'm more experienced whit this I create a Squad test to see how wrong was I printing. Also, I create a "NOT A SQUAD" stl that prints 90 degrees in my printer, so I will use it to reasemble the printer and correct this structural failure. I beleve that the structure parts was not cuted correctly. I'll try to fix that first by sanding if I can.

Anyway. Test your printer and share your results !!! All yo need is to print the squad test and compare it whit a squad or a compass.

Good Luck !! :)
Nacho.

description.text: This is a simple and robust Arduino Nano enclosure. Seals with 12mm #4 screws. It has full access to USB and all pins. It's intended to sit within an electronics enclosure and provide a secure way to hold a Nano, while still being easy to remove.

title: Universal Drone Canopy - Beluga Roll Cage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Beluga Roll Cage

This is a universal roll cage designed to fit most quadcopters, included is a template that you simply place over the standard 30.5mm FC holes to then mark and drill 4 holes using a 3mm drill bit. The roll cage comes equipped with a hs1177 or similar camera mount and it uses 4 regular 35mm standoffs.

Printing directions:
Print the roll cage with the holes for the standoffs pointing up, I personally use 4 perimeters / walls and 4 top / bottom walls, 0.3mm resolution and supports for just the camera mount hole (I achieve this by setting the minimum angle for supports to 80 degrees)

Most items on sale!:

  • Motors (budget option): link
  • Motors (quality option): link
  • ESC:link
  • FC: link
  • Battery: link
  • FPV Cam + VTX: link
  • HD recording: link

Notes:

Print the roll cage with the holes for the standoffs pointing up, I personally use 4 perimeters / walls and 4 top / bottom walls, 0.3mm resolution and supports for just the camera mount hole (I achieve this by setting the minimum angle for supports to 80 degrees)

author: jdcanado

description.text:
OpenForge
=========
Dungeon edge curved tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles. This set also includes half curved floor tiles (with built in edge buffer) for dealing with curved that have playing area on both sides of the wall.
The smooth set can be used for any number of things. Look at the Smooth floor tile set for ideas. There, I've done concrete, ice and dirt. Here I've done concrete.
These tiles are designed to line their wall up with walls from tiles butted up against their neighbours. These are designed to be used on the edge of the map or to give more usable space for the play area, particularly for 1x hallways which would be impossible to fit mins in unless the wall was moved. Because the wall now takes up some space, you will need to use edge buffers in some places to get the tiles to lay out properly.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Printed in black.  Painted with successive layers of dry brush of grey, tope, and light grey.  Cracks are painted with wider lines of the light grey and a thinner line of black.
